concept.title: Touch points, interactions, and events
concept.shortdesc: Touch points are points on a path where customers and an organization make contact, or attempt to make contact. Each touch point is associated with a specific interaction, called an event.

conbody.p: The customer paths in reports can include any events that are shared with by event publishers through IBM Universal Behavior Exchange (UBX).

For each channel in a path, you can gain a deeper understanding of how customers interacted in the channel by comparing the different events that occurred in the channel. Event types vary according to channel, and they can be initiated by customers or by your company. Examples of customer-initiated events include Cart Purchase, Conversion, and Email Open.
Looking at the events that are associated with each channel in a customer path can help you answer the following types of questions:

li.p: What are the most common customer behaviors within a channel? For example, when customers visit your website, what do they do most often?
What are the most common events across all channels in the path? For example, if customers experience a struggle in the web channel, do they also experience struggles in other channels?
For an event that can occur in more than one channel, is it more common in one channel than in another? For example, do more customers watch a video on your website than on your mobile application?

conbody.p: For more information about events, see the IBM Universal Behavior Exchange documentation.
